I don’t want to sound like an A. Hole and I liked all three projects but here’s what I hate and like about them about them:
The first one: we don’t need it. Period- the reason is that the it can only help people with myopia or presbyopia and not people with astigmatism which is actually very common and I’m not even talking about other complex cases (only regarding the curvature of the cornea or defects with the lenses) like Keratoconus. Not to mention we already a have a machine like this called AutoRef which I use widely. Finally, a professional is definitely required for and is other data like intra ocular pressure, disc, retina check etc before we come to any conclusions.
The second one: swear to god I was actually impressed and I wanted her to win. She used a simple formula formula and a simple graph. I studied that in 10th grade but her research was amazing and she was really confident during the interview. I felt like she had a goal and was keen to learn more.
The third one: again a good project but I’d rather say that a good chemical analysis should be done by professionals in case of natural water bodies and since most of the people drink RO water these days, it’d be a futile product however that is indeed a good instrument for basic analysis and research or fo countries where people drink water directly from the natural source (idk why there’d be As in a natural water body that I secluded). Also, chemicals aren’t the only pollutants, biological contamination is also a thing- being about to measure biological oxygen demand would be really helpful.
These young people are (should be at least) the real influencers. I wish the best for my 7 years old son to be influenced by them.

I'm surprised it was the student who didn't need lots of money to develop a prototype that won. Usually it's kids with means (wealthy parents, or those who are at least well-off enough that they can scrape together hundreds to thousands of dollars to help their child construct advanced prototypes) that can win these types of events. Unfortunately, that sort of thing permeates the field and causes a lot of bright students who could come up with revolutionary ideas to never be able to apply any of them because they simply don't have the funding to explore their ideas fully. And a lot of highly scientific minds don't have the best social skills to 'network' and match up with those who do have the means, or the boldness to push their concepts out to teachers and events such as this (after all, haven't many of us grown up in schools where showing too much abnormal intelligence results in bullying, or outright beatings by the dumber kids?). I'm always depressed to understand how many people grow up with knowledge and ideas that could revolutionize the world, but that live and die in obscurity for various reasons. For every one that overcomes severe adversity, there are probably a hundred who aren't able to. But there is no way to uniformly identify all children with potential and properly nurture them all, so it often is a crap shoot as to which kids really make it.
As for who i expected, i really thought it was the kid who developed the eye test. When i went to an optometrist last year, he said they had purchased an entirely new machine and it made their lives so much easier, and i noticed it wasn't the same multi-lens system as usual-so this kid probably got a patent and has made a fortune off of it. Unless someone else had something similar come out around the same time

Everyone thinks that the first guy did the best but what most don't know is that the liquid lens technology was already around and he just found a innovative way to take advantage of it. The same probably went for the girl who made the arsenic detector as well since the chemistry was already discovered and all she did was package it neatly into a commercially viable product.
However, the reason the girl with the maths formula won is because she thought up of an ingenious method of optimising the search for exoplanets. This was probably never thought of before and could now help scientists and astronomers rediscover planets they perhaps missed.
Usually, the engineers are the ones who lose these competitions since they are often looked down in the scientific community by physicists and mathematicians since it was them who first discovered the technology or the new maths that the engineers use.
Personally, I don't feel that it's fair since engineering is needed much more and it has a much higher impact on the world practically speaking than newly discovered research. After all, it is the engineers who build the world while the physicist only dreams and fantasizes.

Hey, how does Ronak Roy's device check for Astigmatism ?     I suffer from this myself, and thus my glasses compensate for this specific condition.   Astigmatism is caused by the cornea of the eye being irregularly shaped, usually like the side of a football, which prevents the proper refraction of light and creates multiple focal points on the retina.This creates a blurry image. One common fix for this problem is corrective lenses that compensate for shape of the cornea.

Ronak's replacement for the phoropter, while it didn't win this award, probably has a fast-track for commercial adoption.   And it's not just about third-world adoption.  Phoropters are very expensive and require a lot of specialist training to use properly.  Attention has been paid to the inexpensive 3d-printed frame, but that's almost a distraction - that part will be injection-molded in a production model, or even made with metal construction - the advance which truly reduces costs is the lens itself, which obviates the need to grind multiple sets of incredibly precise optics and replaces them with some rather inexpensive electronics and fluid mechanics.  The reward is (probably properly) more biased toward pure science and away from applied science, but for applied science, the phoropter seems pretty exciting.  I suspect we'll hear more about it.

I knew who the winner would be after listening to their projects.
1) The replacement for glass lenses is a good idea for a startup, it is essentially a working prototype and can be mass produced after it is redesigned.
2) The winner had something that can and most likely will contribute to the science in a very dramatic way. I am sure there was a lot more to her idea than she explained, just a representation of probability or characteristics of possible planetoids that are undetectable is too abstract. This is where i had my initial doubts, but after reading the abstract to her paper she already has used the methods she described to locate over 500 missed planets.
3) A good startup idea again, not really much contribution to pure science, just practical device. And although camera detection is easier to implement because of ready available arduino boards, it is not in any way a good solution. She should have used an electronic detection of the concentration, instead of taking a picture, parsing it, comparing with known results.. Not only the color of the samples will have an influence on the result but also the lighting, the camera quality, etc. But the device has potential.


Overall 1 and 3 can earn millions if they sell their apparatus, but 2 has a potential for real contribution to science.

1. First guy --- nothing deep. Just the basic physics is implemented to do something, which may be useful. Especially it is attractive because it is adapted to modern era, in which everything can be done with an app. It is also somewhat original at least in the regard of being practical.
2. It looks like she does not totally understand what she is talking about. Moreover, I am sure this field is a subject of research with serious scientists engaged, so she does not stand a chance to contribute anything valuable.
3. I am sure that there is an industrial production of stuff like she suggests and people that produce it know what they are doing much better than this girl. Also, it is not clear what is here contribution to the final product. She wrote a program that identifies the color from the camera?

So, I am voting for the first guy.

PS: In any case, it is clear, that all three had substantial support from senior people: they were explained what to do and taught what to say. This is not how a good scientist, independent by definition, should work. To me it is more of a freak show, for children of parents with failed ambitions.

PPS: Having watched the video and finding out what was the choice of the referees, I watched the presentation of Ana once again. As I understand, the point is as follows. Assume, we observed two planets with known masses and radii of orbiting (I am not sure that one can get this info by measuring a dip in brightness). Then, the question is: what are the radius of the orbit and the mass of the planet that one can put in between the observed two planets without destroying stability of their orbits. My main problem is that I do not understand where the plot on 5:25 comes from. I assume, this is a previously obtained result. In any case, I do not see how it can be obtained knowing only the school physics. It requires good understanding of how the four-body physics works. Only two-body systems can be solved analytically and many of high school seniors are struggling to understand even this simple problem. Four-body systems can be either simulated on computers, or one can use some sort of perturbation theory analytically to get approximate results. In any case, this is far beyond what students know how to do in school. So, I am wondering, what is the actual Ana's contribution. Speaking of utility (and omitting the fact that observations of dips, most likely, are not sufficient to identify masses and radii of orbits), possibility of presence of additional planets does not imply that they are, indeed, present there.

I also looked up the web and found stuff like "Ana Humphrey created her first environmental education project at age ten after learning how mountaintop removal coal mining devastated mountain ecosystems and community health". Does anyone really take this crap seriously? And 250 000 is the quarter of the Nobel price, btw, for which serious people are working their asses off the whole life. I guessed correctly, Ana deserved it. I am an Aerospace Engineer and I could see clearly that not only did she have a brilliant solution to a question she genuinely was curious about, but she exhibited the characteristics of a scientist who really cares about a broad understanding of the world around her. Considering he said they were asked challenging questions on challenging topics, she seemed most likely to answer those best. The other kids were not dumb by any means, but their inventions seemed more about getting recognition than a genuine scientific curiosity.

For those who don't have astigmatism, it appeared that Ronak's phoropter did not address the cylindrical lens correction that is needed to full define a modern eye glass prescription. His device only had an adjustable spherical lens, the other half of the lens prescription often includes a cylindrical correction and associated angle. It's an interesting idea, but not extremely useful, especially when you still need to, you know, get a pair of glasses manufactured and fit to a frame to actually treat the condition. Also it seems it is not his original idea, this has been done several times since 2011 and there is already a product available that does this. https://iovs.arvojournals.org/article.aspx?articleid=2356201
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-14507-5
https://www.adaptica.com/products/visionfit/

Anjali had a decent idea, but it seemed over engineered to check enough boxes to sound good. She applied well known chemistry to solve a simple problem then she used a test strip to detect the arsenic (nothing wrong with that), but THEN she went to a lot of trouble to further convolute the process and throw in unnecessary steps, there was nothing original or interesting about using an arduino and capturing a photo. She was self-aggrandizing by calling it a "mathematical model" she "wrote" to make the conversion of the color data to concentration data.... That's a trivial task she chose to call a "mathematical model", she also tried to use as many buzz words as possible including "embedded electronics", "the cloud". It was unsurprising that when she saved data to "the cloud" (i.e. an internet database/website) multiple people can access it, that's what the internet is all about. She seems like she is more inclined to be a business person than a scientist, a Steve Jobs, not a Steve Wozniak.

Like I said, they're not stupid kids, but given the idea behind the prize, Ana (out of the three shown here) clearly deserved the award.

I knew somebody who won a science fair like this,

Back when I was in 11th grade, a senior in my high school called Amber Yang created a machine learning algorithm that could create 3D models of low earth orbiting space junk. The AI she created was able to use a limited sample size of orbital and object size data collected about real space junk, then use this data to predict what the sizes and possible orbits of additional objects could be. The way she tested her program was to use public data bases on the locations of space junk, take a few of the objects in the data base, and using her AI, see how many objects it could predict that also happened to be in the data base. She was able to successfully predict the orbits of other space junk to a 97% accuracy. Considering the best technology that NASA used at the time only was able to predict to a 62% accuracy, this was a vast improvement. She attended the 2017 Intel International Science and Engineering Fair and won second place, a $50,000 dollar reward, has given Ted talks, and a lecture at the Large Hadron Collider in Geneva, Switzerland. I have not spoken with her in a couple years now but I believe she founded her own company to continue her research and development of the technology and works with NASA on implementing her technology into the tracking and discovery of new space junk.

Abstract for a poster given by Ana Humphrey at the American Astronomical Society Meeting:

Title : Finding Exoplanets by Assessing the Dynamical Packing of Kepler Multi-Candidate Systems

Barnes' and Raymond's Packed Planetary System (PPS) hypothesis postulates that planetary formation is efficient and creates dynamically-packed planetary systems that cannot contain additional planets. Here I look for unpacked spaces in Kepler multi-candidate systems that should, according to a PPS corollary, contain planets. In doing so, a "roadmap" was created to find potential unidentified planets. Previous research suggests that a system's dynamical packing can be quantified using the dynamical spacing Δ: the number of mutual Hill radii between adjacent planets (a "planet pair"). Using previously proposed values for minimum Δ (10, 12.3, and 21.7) required for planet pair orbital stability, I determine whether planet pairs in Kepler multi-candidate systems could host an intermediate body (an "unpacked pair"). For each Kepler unpacked pair, the maximum mass of an intermediate body that the pair could host while remaining in stable orbits ("mass capacity") and the semimajor axis at which this mass could be hosted were calculated. Next, the probable masses were determined. Known packed planet triplets were surveyed to determine the mass capacity each middle planet uses. It was found that 95% of middle planets have a semimajor axis that fall within a 12.45% semimajor axis deviation of the ideal semimajor axis. Furthermore, the results suggest that Kepler multicandidate systems have space for as many as 559 unidentified intermediate planets assuming a minimum Δ = 12.3. Median mass efficiencies suggest that of these planets exist, 28% could be Earth or Super Earth-sized. If the unpacked pairs are due to missing planets as suggested by PPS, the predicted mass and semimajor axis for these potential planets may facilitate detection by characterizing expected transit and radial velocity signals. However, the large number of unpacked pairs might also be explained by variations of PPS (for example, systems that start packed and become unstable over time) or alternate system architecture hypotheses.

I'd just like to write a simple reply to all the people talking about their vinegar volcanos in high school. It's not that kids have gotten ridiculously smarter than back in the day, but rather that the amount of technology and knowledge they have access to is vastly larger. The first "invention", for instance, is just an autorefractor. It's nothing new. He didn't even come up with the idea of making one with simple off the shelf components, there have been tutorials on how to build one for years. So, all he did was google for an interesting project, go on Amazon, and order the components, a controllable liquid lens, a raspberry pi, and some miscellaneous parts, then integrated a bunch of fairly standard and pre-existing code, and built a simple app, then 3d-printed a part to bring it all together. And he had the help of his teachers to do it too.


Which is essentially the same thing you did 30 years ago, except you didn't have the internet, so you went to the local library, and you didn't have amazon, and you couldn't order massively powerful computers the size of a credit card for a few bucks either. That's why you came up with a vinegar volcano and he has an autorefractor.


The other difference is that back then teachers weren't trying to get likes on the internet, and so they they didn't try and embellish what you did. Now they do, and when they present this they try to upsell what the kids did.

How many of the kids that went to this competition would be considered living in poverty? I've just always wondered how kids can do stuff like this and what is holding other kids back. Growing up, I loved math and science, but despite how much my parents encouraged me, there was only so much they could do without many resources. It would always make me so angry hearing about "This kid has created some revolutionary invention in his garage" and then they would show the garage and its some epic workshop, or hearing about how "This genius kid has graduated college at age 12" and then they would say that this kid was born with some special talent like photographic memory or some human calculator level ability. Now, of course there are outliers, like that story about the kid in Africa who built an automatic scarecrow thing that scared lions away from his livestock, but these are very far and few between. For me, I remember the science I did with my friend was where we built a watermill into our roof gutter that would turn on a lightbulb when it rained. Eventually it stopped working though because the wires we used rusted away. I can only wonder what we could have done if we had the money or the connections that these kids have. All I'm saying is that we shouldn't be proud of these kids. They don't deserve the praise.

"For 57 years, the contest was known as the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, or simply “the Westinghouse.” While attending the 1939 New York World’s Fair, G. Edward Pendray, a Westinghouse executive, and Watson Davis, director of Science Service (now Society for Science & the Public) began discussing ways to encourage more students to pursue science careers. They decided on a national competition - Westinghouse agreed to provide prize money and cover administrative costs and Science Service took on the task of running it. In 1998, Intel Corporation became the title sponsor of the competition, continuing what has become an American institution designed to encourage young people to pursue careers in science, math, engineering and medicine. In 2016, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals became the next sponsor to carry on the Science Talent Search."
